text:
EFL syria-l World Cup 2018: Syria could defy all the odds and make it to Russia despite devastating civil war which is destroying country 
Middle Eastern state play 'home' fixtures in Malaysia — and face massive crunch clash against South Korea in Seoul By Andrew Richardson Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Comments SYRIA could defy all the odds and write one of the most amazing chapters of football history by reaching their first-ever World Cup. 
The war-torn country are currently fourth in their group following a last-gasp win over Uzbekistan. EPA 11 Syria beat Uzbekistan and could realistically make World Cup play-off spot 
And a shock victory over South Korea could see them leapfrog the Asiatic giants into second place and an automatic qualification spot. 
The top two in the group are automatically granted their place in Russia, with the third-place sides advancing to a continental play-off. 
It’s been a harrowing period for Syria . 
The Middle Eastern state has been engulfed in a civil war for the best part of six years — with horrifying stories emerging from the tragic conflict. Seeing Red Keith Gillespie launches viscous elbow into face of opponent during Man United charity match 'We'll talk soon' Mesut Ozil gives clearest indication yet he is set to sign a new deal with Arsenal in the summer 'I don't even like football' Neil Taylor is hammered on Twitter after breaking Seamus Coleman’s leg… but it’s an ex-councillor not the Wales defender taking the brunt of the abuse NO RESPECT Arsenal striker Alexis Sanchez upsets Chile team-mates with fan-snubbing tantrum after Argentina defeat Big neym signing Man Utd in 'talks with Neymar's agent over £173m move and £416k-a-week deal' Tied down Chelsea 'agree' £35m fee with Monaco for midfield star Tiemoue Bakayoko on lucrative five-year deal Reuters Syria players celebrate after securing a historic victory away against China EPA 11 Syria’s Omar Khrbin in action against Uzbekistan in Malaysia 
Much of the country is part an Isis stronghold, with Syrian governmental forces battling hard to regain territory. 
And many of the country’s best footballers have been forced to flee. 
Given the security fears and economic sanctions, their home fixtures are played over 4,500 miles away in Malaysia. 
Despite having little — if any — support, they are making a genuine fight of qualifying for the World Cup . 
There has been nothing to smile about in Syria over the past six years, but this could at least provide some form of joy to the people. Getty Images Syria’s Omar Kharbin puts a tackle in on Qatar’s Luiz Ceara during 1-0 defeat EPA 11 Syria home games take place in Malaysia without any support 
With 90 minutes on the clock and score still goalless against Uzbekistan in Krubong, the ‘home side’s’ prospects were looking bleak. 
But 23-year-old Omar Kharbin showed immense coolness beyond his age when given the chance to snatch the victory in stoppage time from 12 yards — stepping up to convert a Panenka-style penalty. 
To give it a little context, the victory over Uzbekistan earned the players a bonus of £800, which is a year’s wages for a Syrian footballer. Getty Images Syria earned a famous 0-0 draw against runaway group leaders, Iran Getty Images 11 Syria’s Zaher Almedani heads the ball during 0-0 qualifying draw with Iran 
And a figure many in the country can only dream about, given the currency has devalued by 1,000 per cent since the start of the conflict. 
In October, Syria defied all the odds when they went to China — who have invested billions on improving their football infrastructure and has a population of 1.4bn — and won 1-0. 
While they are above 2022 World Cup hosts, Qatar, in their group, and even held high-fliers, Iran, to a 0-0 draw. Getty Images Syria head coach Ayman Hakeem would create folklore with World Cup appearance EPA 11 South Korea prepare for their massive World Cup qualifier against Syria 
And now, they face the biggest match in their history as they travel to Seoul to face World Cup regulars, South Korea. 
Victory would put them on the brink of football folklore. 
While Syria qualifying for the World Cup would surely be the greatest sporting story of all-time, compared to the devastation the country’s people are suffering, this would be a walk in the park. Jemain Defoe holds Bradley Lowery's hand as they lead the England team out at Wembley
